Award.AwardTitle: IDBR: TYPE A Ultrahigh Spatial Resolution Sub-organelle Molecular Mass Spectrometry Imaging Using Liquid Metal Ion Beam Desorption and Radiofrequency Ionization
Award.AbstractNarration:
An award is made to Baylor University to develop an ultrahigh spatial resolution mass spectrometry imaging (MSI) instrument. The potential impact of this research is far-reaching because no current technology is available to address the existing shortcomings in high spatial resolution MSI. The direct beneficiaries of this state-of-the-art technology will include students, researchers, and the society as a whole. This work is expected to open the door for a variety of technology transfer opportunities and potential industry collaborations with the university for mass production that will yield significant economic and societal benefits. Two qualified undergraduate students from underrepresented groups from Baylor outreach programs will be recruited to gain quality research experience. Moreover, two graduate students and a scientist will be trained in research activities and develop expertise in MSI to broaden their scientific knowledge. Research findings and presentations of all mentees in the project will be highlighted in annual Advanced Instrumentation Workshops that target undergraduate students and faculty mentors from Historically Black Colleges and Universities and Hispanic-serving institutions in Texas and nearby states. Virtual scientific networks will be used to disseminate research findings and promote new collaborations. These NSF supported activities will be used to broaden underrepresented student group participation in future biological MSI research. This research will allow construction of a cutting-edge molecular imaging instrument that will be accessed by Baylor faculty and students and utilized for teaching advanced instrumentation classes and to promote inter-institution collaborations. Outcomes from this research will be disseminated through publications and conference presentations to boost broader use of the new ultrahigh spatial resolution MSI.

Mass spectrometry imaging (MSI) provides information on surface morphology but also generates highly desired details about specific molecular identities of different sample components. In conventional MSI, a primary laser or desorption beam is rastered across a sample surface to desorb and subsequently analyze different components of biological tissues to construct three-dimensional images. Hence, the spatial resolution in MSI is limited by desorption beam's dimensions (or laser footprint) and energy threshold required to desorb a sufficient number of substrate molecules from the surface for subsequent ionization and mass analysis. Moreover, low ionization efficiencies can severely limit both sensitivity and spatial resolution (typically to several microns) for characterization of cellular components. The purpose of this research is to provide novel analytical capabilities for highly specific and sensitive characterization of cell organelles at the molecular level. This project will create a new frontier in MSI by combining focused ion beam (FIB) neutral desorption with a newly discovered and highly efficient radio frequency ionization (RFI). Persistent challenges in subcellular MSI include achievement of adequate detection sensitivity, overcoming ionization bias, minimizing potential migration of substrate constituents during the analysis, and improving spatial resolution. Current MSI strategies typically address one of these challenges at the expense of another. To ameliorate current trade-offs in MSI, geometry of an RFI source will be optimized to ionize substantially larger portion of the desorbed neutral plume than currently possible. The unparalleled sensitivity of RFI is expected to reduce the primary beam power requirements for a liquid metal ion source (LMIS) to such an extent that imaging resolution in the x-y (surface) and z (depth) dimensions will support molecular level characterization. It will be possible to record 3D images and characterize cell structures and compositions to an unprecedented level of detail, with spatial resolutions an order of magnitude better than current MSI approaches.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant funded development of an ultra-high spatial resolution mass spectrometry imaging (MSI) instrument that can provide new analytical capabilities for highly specific and sensitive characterization of cell organelles at the molecular level. This system utilizes a focused ion beam (FIB) for desorption and radio-frequency ionization (RFI) for imparting charge on the desorbed species for ultra-high-resolution mass measurement with a Fourier transform-ion cyclotron resonance mass spectrometer (FT-ICR MS). Because there were no commercially available control systems to manage all the necessary components of our proposed high-resolution imaging mass spectrometry instrument (including sample stage elements, FIB components, RFI source, quadrupole ion storage devices, ion cyclotron resonance cell segments, etc.), we designed and developed our own vacuum chamber and associated control systems. The instrument development stage of the project provided excellent training opportunities for undergraduate students, graduate students, and senior personnel in interdisciplinary areas including, bioinformatics, biology, biochemistry, chemistry, computer science, ion optics/physics, and engineering design.

As a direct result of the necessary developments and incorporation of advanced digital electronics, we have established collaborations with engineers, chemists, and clinical researchers both in academia and industry. Through these collaborations we have been able to design and construct one of the most technologically capable multi-component instrument control systems. Early on, we identified 1) adaptability, 2) capability, and 3) accessibility as the three primary requirements for the instrument control platform for our system.

The primary goal of this project was not just the creation of a powerful instrument, but also making this instrument available for use by other researches. As such, we prioritized ease-of-use in the form of user-friendly software and easily understandable and reproducible electronics. Examples of this can be seen throughout the Data Station One (DSO) software platform, where ease-of-use is maintained without sacrificing capability and adaptability, as well as in the electronics, where almost exclusively off-the-shelf components have been used.

Continued development of this high-performance instrument will benefit the following biological research communities: cancer research, cell/molecular/system biology, drug development, pharmaceutical research, cell physiology, microbiology, pathology/pathophysiology, medical sciences, and imaging fields. Improvements to the development of this TYPE A instrument is an ongoing process and brings us closer to revolutionizing current understanding of cell biology. We are exploring new frontiers in MSI through decoupling of desorption and ionization processes and thus far we have been able to demonstrate that large biomolecules can remain intact after the desorption via FIB.   

Funding this project has opened doors for a number of collaborations between our group and academic institutions and industry on brain, liver, and lung imaging. We have published several manuscripts on instrument design, method developments, software developments, and complex data analyses in peer-reviewed journals. We have also shared our findings in conference proceedings, workshops, invited oral presentations, and public forums (museums, rotary clubs, etc.). Graduate and undergraduate students gained quality research experiences in MSI to broaden their scientific knowledge and help them excel in the career endeavors. Several undergraduate students were recruited to this project from Baylor outreach programs to increase students? participation from underrepresented groups. Students? research findings and work were presented in regional and national conferences (via posters presentations and talks) and peer reviewed high-impact factor journals (publications). All mentees in the project also participated in Baylor University annual Advanced Instrumentation Workshops to highlight their research and recruit new quality students. These NSF supported activities have broaden underrepresented student group participation in biological MSI research. It also funded construction of a cutting-edge molecular imaging instrument that can be accessed by Baylor faculty and students and utilized for teaching advanced instrumentation classes.

The PI has established strong industry partnerships that will facilitate knowledge transfer and commercialization. We will continue to use the research outcomes from IDBR funding to procure NSF?s Grant Opportunities for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) or possible Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) type funding mechanisms to develop next generation FIB-RFI imaging system.
